content.raw: The real hands are capable of much faster motions, and have much less intrinsic damping. This value was chosen quickly just to ensure stability in the simulation, as it is challenging to have very small links (the finger links) in the same system as very large links (the heavier parts of the robot). You should feel free to play around with all of these values, and we will gladly accept feedback.
content.html: The real hands are capable of much faster motions, and have much less intrinsic damping. This value was chosen quickly just to ensure stability in the simulation, as it is challenging to have very small links (the finger links) in the same system as very large links (the heavier parts of the robot). You should feel free to play around with all of these values, and we will gladly accept feedback.

content.raw:
We would like to be able to move the fingers at the maximum velocity of the real hand. (do you have any data on that?).

We will try to change the parameters and see how it works for us, given a good balance between realistic inertia, damping and maximum velocity. Other teams might have input on this as well.
content.html:
We would like to be able to move the fingers at the maximum velocity of the real hand. (do you have any data on that?).

We will try to change the parameters and see how it works for us, given a good balance between realistic inertia, damping and maximum velocity. Other teams might have input on this as well.

content.raw: I'm afraid to make an intuition-type guess on this without real data to back it up. I'll try to generate some data in the next few days. I would suggest experimenting with roughly human-scale speeds for now.
content.html: I'm afraid to make an intuition-type guess on this without real data to back it up. I'll try to generate some data in the next few days. I would suggest experimenting with roughly human-scale speeds for now.

content.raw:
Doing some tests we have found that it is probably not necessarily to change the inertia parameters to reduce the damping. We were able to grasp the drill using our hand controller with the following changes:

- Reduce damping to 0.1
- Reduce joint limit gains in the safety_controller from 1000.0 to 100.0
- Disable maximum velocity, or increase it to a very high number like 1000.0. Due the low inertia, the maximum velocity is easily violated and an unstable behavior arises. I do not think that limiting the finger velocity is necessary for the simulation. 


It seems that the joint limits are actually causing the instability.

The velocity measurement of the finger joints in the simulation is very poor (loads of noise) and it doesn't look like increasing damping solves much there. We use a low-pass filter to measure velocity and have the damping in our PD controller extremely low. 

We also saw the behavior described in this bug report
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint

Depending on how the velocity limits are implemented, this could lead to oscillations on contact with an object.

I uploaded my new urdf.xacro files to my repository, you can find them here
https://bitbucket.org/jespersmith/gazebostatecommunicator/src/4b84fd75562c009abccd8465fdc8d8edf94c9638/launch/models/modifiable?at=default
content.html:
Doing some tests we have found that it is probably not necessarily to change the inertia parameters to reduce the damping. We were able to grasp the drill using our hand controller with the following changes:

  • Reduce damping to 0.1
  • Reduce joint limit gains in the safety_controller from 1000.0 to 100.0
  • Disable maximum velocity, or increase it to a very high number like 1000.0. Due the low inertia, the maximum velocity is easily violated and an unstable behavior arises. I do not think that limiting the finger velocity is necessary for the simulation.

It seems that the joint limits are actually causing the instability.

The velocity measurement of the finger joints in the simulation is very poor (loads of noise) and it doesn't look like increasing damping solves much there. We use a low-pass filter to measure velocity and have the damping in our PD controller extremely low.

We also saw the behavior described in this bug report https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint

Depending on how the velocity limits are implemented, this could lead to oscillations on contact with an object.

I uploaded my new urdf.xacro files to my repository, you can find them here https://bitbucket.org/jespersmith/gazebostatecommunicator/src/4b84fd75562c009abccd8465fdc8d8edf94c9638/launch/models/modifiable?at=default

content.raw: Joint velocity measurements with and without velocity limits
content.html: Joint velocity measurements with and without velocity limits

content.raw:
I made some graphs of the joint velocities given 0.2 Nm open loop torque on f0_j1 and plotted the resulting velocity. Setting the velocity limits to 1 rad/s results in a lot of chatter around the limit, see 0.2NmVelocityLimits.png and compare to the plot with no limits in 0.2NmNoLimits.png.

When the joint is in contact, there is also a lot of chatter around the velocity limit due to [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint) making the system unstable at moderate joint torque. The attached graph 2NmVelocityLimitsInContact shows quite well what is happening.

Setting the damping to 30 Nm/rad/s, and given the effort limit of 28, will result in a system that never reaches the velocity limits and thus is stable. We think that disabling the velocity limits on the fingers avoids a lot of simulation instability.
content.html:
I made some graphs of the joint velocities given 0.2 Nm open loop torque on f0_j1 and plotted the resulting velocity. Setting the velocity limits to 1 rad/s results in a lot of chatter around the limit, see 0.2NmVelocityLimits.png and compare to the plot with no limits in 0.2NmNoLimits.png.

When the joint is in contact, there is also a lot of chatter around the velocity limit due to https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint making the system unstable at moderate joint torque. The attached graph 2NmVelocityLimitsInContact shows quite well what is happening.

Setting the damping to 30 Nm/rad/s, and given the effort limit of 28, will result in a system that never reaches the velocity limits and thus is stable. We think that disabling the velocity limits on the fingers avoids a lot of simulation instability.

content.raw:
Hm, that probably means [velocity limit implementation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/dae44f8efd4eddfe5d0e47f614d9b1fb0abfd3bb/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEHingeJoint.cc?at=default#cl-163) is non-ideal.  We can go ahead and:

  1. disable the limits in Sandia had for now.
  1. address [velocity limit implementation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/634/joint-velocity-limit-causes-significant).
content.html:
Hm, that probably means velocity limit implementation is non-ideal. We can go ahead and:

  1. disable the limits in Sandia had for now.
  2. address velocity limit implementation.

Can we go ahead and assume that the velocity limits will be large enough such that we can quickly open and close the hands?

As damping parameter we have been using 0.1 Nm/rad/s, do you have an idea what the final value will be?

Maybe a better implementation would be to use a penalty function instead of setting the effort to zero at the velocity limit. For example, 

if ( velocity > maxVelocity)
{
     damping =  - Kv * (velocity - maxVelocity);
     effort = effort + damping;
}
else ( velocity < -maxVelocity)
{
     damping =  - Kv * (velocity - -maxVelocity);
     effort = effort + damping;
}

Where Kv is a tuned limit gain. However, if the measured joint velocity is positive when the fingers are stationary and in contact with an object any velocity limit will probably lead to instability or lower than desired torques.
